headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to the Aetna Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I'll now turn the conference over to Mr. Tom Cowhey, Vice President
componenttext: Good morning and welcome to the Aetna Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I'll now turn the conference over to Mr. Tom Cowhey, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Cowhey, please go ahead.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining Aetna's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Call and Webcast. This is Tom Cowhey, Vice President of Investor Relations for Aetna. And with me this morning are Aetna's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Mar
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining Aetna's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Call and Webcast. This is Tom Cowhey, Vice President of Investor Relations for Aetna. And with me this morning are Aetna's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Mark Bertolini; and Chief Financial Officer, Sean Guertin. 
Following the prepared portion of the remarks, we will answer your questions. Mr. Rowen, Aetna's President, will join Mark and Sean for the Q&A session. 
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements. Risk factors that may impact those statements and could cause actual future results to differ materially from currently projected results are described in this morning's press release and the reports we filed with the SEC, including our 2013 Form 10-K, our 2014 Form 10-Qs and our 2014 Form 10-K when filed. We have provided reconciliations of metrics related to the company's performance that are non-GAAP measures in our fourth quarter 2014 financial supplement and our updated 2015 guidance summary, copies of which are available on the Investor Information section of aetna.com. 
Finally, as you know, our ability to respond to certain inquiries from investors and analysts in nonpublic forms is limited, so we invite you to ask all questions that of material nature on this call. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Mark Bertolini. Mark?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you, Tom, and thank you, all, for joining us today. This morning, we reported full year 2014 operating EPS of $6.70, representing a record result for the company, the high-end of our previous annual projection, year-over-year growth in
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you, Tom, and thank you, all, for joining us today. This morning, we reported full year 2014 operating EPS of $6.70, representing a record result for the company, the high-end of our previous annual projection, year-over-year growth in excess of 7% and an operating EPS CAGR of 15% since 2010. 
Looking back on 2014. We solved or priced for nearly $1 billion of new fees and taxes; achieved pretax margins in excess of our initial 2014 projections; accelerated Coventry synergies, achieving a run rate in 2014 that will deliver at least $0.90 of operating EPS accretion in 2015; closing out our commitments to shareholders; enrolled nearly 600,000 public exchange members, while exceeding our initial profitability projections in this new program; bolstered our consumer platform through the acquisition of BSwift; and continue to advance our efforts to ship the network model for patient-centric population health management. Our 2014 results are a testament to the strength of our leadership team and the execution of our growth strategy. Underlying these full year results, we ended the year with more than 23.5 million medical members, well in excess of our previous projections and representing full year growth of approximately 1.4 million members. We reported record operating revenue of nearly $58 billion, including organic growth of approximately 13% across multiple lines of business. We reported a full year commercial medical benefit ratio, that absent our conservative stance on our ACA-compliant blocks of business and higher-than-projected flu, would have been at the lower end of our previous 2014 projections. Our full year Commercial benefit ratio of 80.2% was a very good result, as aggregate Commercial medical cost trend increases remain moderate, and our 51 to 300 employee block perform consistent with our previous projections. Our operating expense ratio, excluding the impact of Health Care Reform, fees and taxes, improved by 100 basis points, as we grew operating revenue and continue to focus on synergy realization. Finally, we generated strong cash flow in 2014, which enabled us to continue to invest in our growth strategy, closed 2 acquisitions, pay down debt, increase our shareholder dividend and still repurchase $1.2 billion of our shares. Our strong finish to 2014, in combination with our strong start to 2015, gives us the confidence this morning to increase our 2015 operating EPS projection to at least $7 per share. As always, this projection does not include any projection of prior year development and represents approximately 13% growth over 2014 results when prior year development is excluded. 
In a moment, sean will discuss our 2014 results and 2015 guidance in greater detail, but first, I would like to discuss Aetna's growth strategy and how we are executing on that strategy. At our Investor Conference in December, we highlighted the multiple avenues we have to drive top and bottom line growth. Specifically, we discussed the stability of our Large Group Commercial businesses and the ability of these businesses to continue to produce attractive returns and generate capital, the growth of our Government franchise and the potential for sustained growth in the future and the opportunity for additional growth in our Individual business as exchanges continue to evolve. Additionally, we discussed our continued efforts to help Aetna to transform model for one of episodic care to population health management and our strategy to lead the industry toward a more consumer-oriented marketplace. 
I will now provide a brief update on how we're executing against some of these growth levers. Starting with our Large Group Commercial business. 2014 was another solid year, as most of our Large Group Commercial businesses met or exceeded our initial projections. In particular, our fee-based businesses had an outstanding year. We grew Commercial ASC membership by over 700,000 members for the year and exceeded our initial operating projection. These results demonstrate the ability of our Large Group Commercial businesses to continue to generate solid returns and to provide capital to reinvest for the benefit of our customers and shareholders. 
Moving on to Government business. Our Medicare franchise continues to be a key component of our strategy to grow our Government business, and our 2014 results speak to our successes in this business. During 2014, we grew our Medicare Advantage membership by almost 18% and our Medicare Supplement membership by nearly 20%, results that are well in excess of our industry growth. Additionally, we just completed another highly successful Medicare annual enrollment period, where growth exceeded our initial projections. We now project to grow our Medicare Advantage membership by 90,000 members in the first quarter, including double-digit percentage growth in our Individual Medicare Advantage membership. A key driver of Aetna's Medicare Advantage membership growth trajectory has been our star ratings. And for the second year in a row, approximately 80% of our sales have come through plans rated 4 stars or greater. 
Continuing with Government. Our Medicaid business has had an excellent year in 2014, including over 11,000 members related to our participation in multiple dual-eligible demonstration projects. We grew premium revenue by over 60%, and operating earnings exceeded our initial projections, driven by better underwriting margins in several of our key geographies and a strong prior year development. Looking forward, despite the previously disclosed exit from our Delaware Medicaid contract, we project 2015 to be another strong year of top line growth for our Medicaid franchise, driven primarily by growth from serving dual-eligible and other high-acuity populations. 
Shifting to public exchanges. We are pleased with our first year execution, particularly in light of the well-publicized challenges with the initial launch of the public exchanges. We ended the year with approximately 560,000 on-exchange members, modestly ahead of our most recent projections. Additionally, while the opening enrollment period is still ongoing, we are on track to exceed our initial enrollment projections for 2015. Further, we have successfully transitioned the vast majority of our off-exchange membership to ACA-compliant plans, consistent with our previous projections. As we look at our total Individual business, we now project that we will end the first quarter with approximately 1.1 million members, including up to 800,000 on-exchange members. We believe the strong results validate our strategy are focusing on geographies where we have a competitive cost structure and can provide the greatest value to potential customers. As we entered the second year of this emerging marketplace, we are cautiously optimistic on the potential for public exchanges to develop into an attractive growth opportunity, where we continue to offer value to our customers and generate a reasonable return for our shareholders. 
Let me now spend a few moments discussing our provider transformation efforts. We continue to advance our strategy of collaborating with providers to build a simpler, more integrated health care system, and we continue to make great strides as we: signed contracts with 28 new ACL partners since year-end 2013; launched multiple new products backed by ACL contracts; doubled our members covered by value-based contracts to more than 3 million members; and increased the percentage of our medical cost that run through value-based contract to 28% of total spend. As we continue to focus incentives around improving the health of our members and lowering overall costs, we are moving closer to a health care system that rewards providers for keeping people healthy and ultimately more productive. 
Finally, in 2014, we continue to advance our strategy to become a more consumer-oriented company. For example, in the fourth quarter, we closed the BSwift acquisition. This transaction was an important step forward as it accelerates our efforts to create the leading front-end buy, shop and enroll capabilities necessary to drive the change through a more consumer-oriented marketplace. Additionally, BSwift adds back-end eligibility and benefits administration, an important element for our employer customers as they look to make the transition to define contribution and private exchange models. Combined with the other investments we have been making, including our efforts to transform the provider network model through our health business, our investments in building a new modular administration platform, and consumer-facing tools like I Triage, we are not only preparing for the shift to defined contribution and consumer-oriented models, we are positioning to drive it. 
In summary, as we reflect on the many challenges that we face as a company and an industry last year, our 2014 results demonstrate strong financial fundamentals and execution against our growth strategies. As we begin 2015, I am confident in our strategic direction and the ability to execute, the multiple growth opportunities ahead that Aetna is well positioned to capitalize on and our updated 2015 operating EPS projection of at least $7 per share. 
I would like to thank all of our employees for their dedication in meeting the needs of our customers. By focusing on sound fundamentals, creating new approaches to satisfying customers and generating and deploying capital responsibly, we believe that we can continue to create value for our customers and our shareholders. 
I will now turn the call over to Shawn, who'll provide additional insight into our fourth quarter and full year results and our updated 2015 outlook. Sean?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. Earlier today, we reported full year 2014 operating earnings of $2.4 billion and operating earnings per share of $6.70, results at the high end of our most recent projections and well in excess of our initial g
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. Earlier today, we reported full year 2014 operating earnings of $2.4 billion and operating earnings per share of $6.70, results at the high end of our most recent projections and well in excess of our initial guidance for 2014. Aetna's operating results continue to be supported by strong operating fundamentals as evidenced by double-digit organic revenue growth, robust cash flow, healthy balance sheet metrics and achievement of target operating margins. 
I'll begin with some comments on our overall full year 2014 performance. We grew medical membership by approximately 1.4 million members to more than 23.5 million members, ending the year approximately 100,000 members higher than our previous projection, as a result of stronger than projected December renewals, primarily in Small Group accounts. We grew operating revenue by 23% to a record $58 billion, driven by double-digit organic revenue growth across multiple lines of business and the full year impact of the Coventry acquisition. Our full year Government medical benefit ratio was 84.9%, a very good results and a testament to the execution of our strategy to solve for the meaningful rate cuts to the Medicare Advantage program in 2014, combined with continued strong performance of our Medicaid business. We improved our full year operating expense ratio by 100 basis points, excluding the impact of ACA-related fees, driven by higher operating revenues and continued discipline in controlling costs. Finally, we generated over $1.5 billion in dividends from subsidiaries and returned an equal amount to shareholders in the form of shareholder dividends and share repurchases. 
Looking more specifically at the fourth quarter results. We grew operating revenue by over 12% versus the same quarter last year to $14.8 billion, driven primarily by membership growth in our Government and Commercial businesses. From an operating margin perspective, our businesses continued to perform quite well. Our fourth quarter total medical benefit ratios was 83%, a good overall result and a 90 basis point improvement over the prior year quarter. Our operating expense ratio increased from the same period last year to 19.7%. However, excluding ACA fees from our expenses, our operating expense ratio was essentially flat with the prior year quarter. Our pretax operating margin was 5.5% for the quarter and 7.6% for the year, consistent with our target operating margin range. This result represents Aetna's fifth consecutive year of achieving or exceeding this goal despite an increasing mix of Government and public exchange businesses and the many challenges that faced our industry in 2014. From a balance sheet perspective, we remain confident in the adequacy of our reserves. We experienced favorable prior-period reserve development in the quarter across our Commercial, Medicaid and Medicare products, primarily attributable to third quarter 2014 dates of service. Our reserve growth kept pace with premium growth, and days claims payable were 49.2 days at the end of the quarter, down marginally from the third quarter, primarily as a result of processing improvements but up over 4 days year-over-year. 
Turning to cash flow and capital. Operating cash flows remain strong. Our full year Health Care and Group Insurance operating cash flows were 1.5x operating earnings. We also continue to aggressively deploy capital to create shareholder value, repurchasing approximately 3 million shares in the quarter for $243 million and distributing approximately $79 million through our quarterly shareholder dividend. In summary, our fourth quarter results demonstrate the execution of Aetna's growth strategy, the success of the Coventry integration and the value of our diversified portfolio. 
I will now discuss the key drivers of our fourth quarter performance in greater detail. Beginning with our Commercial business. Our Commercial membership declined by approximately 70,000 members during the quarter, driven by declines in our Individual and Small Group insured books, partially offset by modest ASC membership growth. These results are consistent with our commitment to financially responsible pricing, where we favor margin over membership and price to projected underlying medical cost trends. Our crucial medical benefit ratio was 82% for the quarter and 80.2% for the full year 2014, a good absolute result and consistent with our previous projections despite pressures from an early and more severe flu season. Importantly, the medical cost performance of our core commercial business and specifically, our 51 to 300 employee block, performed consistent with the projections we described on our third quarter 2014 earnings call. Additionally, Aetna's commercial MBR was influenced by our continued prudent stance with regard to our ACA-compliant blocks of business. Based on the most recent data available, we have adjusted our accruals related to the 3Rs during the fourth quarter, specifically, we recorded $176 million of incremental reinsurance recoverable during the quarter, bringing our total for the year to $338 million; we recorded additional net payables for the risk adjusters of $78 million, bringing the net full year total to $230 million; and we did not record any risk corridor receivables as of December 31, 2014. However, in select geographies, we have recorded a modest risk corridor payable where our current projections indicate we will be required to contribute to this program. Had we accrued a risk corridor receivable at December 31, our full year 2014 Commercial MBR would have been lower by approximately 20 basis points. Consistent with our Commercial MBR performance, Aetna's standalone 2014 Commercial manager cost trend was in the middle to upper end of our originally projected range of 6% to 7%, in line with our previous projection. 
Moving on from Commercial. Our Government franchise is another important growth lever for our business. As Mark mentioned earlier, our Government business had an outstanding year from both a growth and profitability standpoint and now represents over 40% of our health care premiums. Our Government business grew by 45,000 members in the quarter, primarily due to Medicaid growth of 26,000 members. Aetna's continued government membership growth drove fourth quarter Government premiums to $5.4 billion, a 19% increase over the prior year period. Over Government medical benefit ratio was 84.4% in the quarter, an excellent result in absolute terms and a 260 basis point improvement over the same period last year. Drivers of this year's excellent performance include favorable prior-period reserve development; the success of actions designed to solve for the Medicare Advantage funding gap, including the health insurer fee; and continuing strong performance in our Medicaid business. Finally, Group Insurance operating earnings were $21.3 million in the quarter compared to $47.9 million in the same quarter of 2013, driven primarily by lower net investment income. For the full year 2014, Group Insurance operating earnings were $171 million, well in excess of 2013 results in our initial full year projections. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Our financial position, capital structure and liquidity all continue to be very strong. At December 31, we had a debt to total capitalization ratio of approximately 37%. 
Looking at cash and investments at the parent. We started the quarter with $100 million. Net subsidiary dividends to the parent were $169 million. We repurchased approximately 3 million shares for $243 million and pay a shareholder dividend of $79 million. After other sources, we ended the quarter with $100 million of cash at the parent, representing our core liquidity. Our basic share count was 349.8 million shares at December 31. 
Moving on to 2015. This morning, we increased our 2015 outlook to at least $7 per share, up from our previous projection of at least $6.90 per share. As a reminder, Aetna's guidance does not include any projections of prior year development. This increased projection reflects the impact of our recently disclosed preferred drug contract for hepatitis C treatments on our Commercial business; higher medical membership than we had previously projected, driven by our solid finish to 2014, and our encouraging early 2015 growth in both our public exchange and Medicare Advantage businesses. These 2 favorable items are partially offset by a projected increase in flu and related costs in 2015 based on the severity of the current flu season. Our 2015 guidance is further influenced by the following drivers. We project that our first quarter medical membership will be approximately 23.5 million members, an increase of approximately 1,000 members versus our previous guidance. Specifically, Aetna's Commercial ASC membership is now projected to decline by approximately 175,000 members, a modest improvement versus our previous guidance. Commercial Insured membership is now projected to be flat to slightly down as compared to year-end 2014, influenced by public and private exchange growth, offset by the previously discussed increase in Small Group renewal activity that occurred in late 2014 rather than in early 2015 and the potential for increased attrition in our smaller Middle Markets and off-exchange Individual businesses. Medicare membership is projected to grow by approximately 120,000 members, comprised of at least 90,000 Medicare Advantage numbers and approximately 30,000 Medicare Supplement members, growth that is again higher than our previous projections. And Medicaid membership is now projected to be better than our previous forecast with other growth almost entirely offsetting the exit from Delaware's Medicaid program. We continue to project full year operating revenue to be at least $62 billion, as the impact of higher-than-projected membership growth on exchanges and Individual Medicare Advantage is projected to be partially offset by the potential for increased attrition in our smaller middle market and off-exchange Individual businesses. We continue to project our full year total health medical benefit ratio to be 82% to 83%. Aetna's 2015 core Commercial Medicare medical cost trend is projected to be in the range of 6% to 7%, reflecting a projected increase in utilization of 50 to 100 basis points over 2014. We project our operating expense ratio will be approximately 18%. This metric is impacted by the increase in expense related to the ACA fees and taxes, which runs to the SG&A line, increasing the reported SG&A ratio for 2015 by approximately 140 basis points. Our underlying operating expense ratio, excluding these fees and taxes, is projected to show improvement over our 2014 result. We project pretax operating margin to be at least 7.3%, consistent with our high single-digit target. We project operating earnings to be over $2.4 billion. And finally, we project net dividends from subsidiaries to be approximately $1.8 billion as additional capital to support growth is held at the subsidiaries. We continue to project excess cash flow to the parent to be in the range of $800 million to $1 billion, noting that increased premiums versus our initial projection could push us into the lower half of this range. 
To the extent that current analyst consensus for 2015 contemplates the same quarterly earnings progression Aetna experienced in 2014, especially as it pertains to the first quarter, we would remind investors that the first quarter of 2014 was favorably impacted by severe winter weather and a lower-than-normal flu season, both of which we do not project to recur in 2015. 
In closing, we are very pleased with the strength of our fourth quarter and full year 2014 results. I want to reiterate that our 2015 operating EPS projection of at least $7 is a floor and that we are committed to delivering results in excess of this early view. To that end, we remain focused on executing on our exchange strategy, both public and private; delivering on our Government growth strategy; improving the performance of our 51 to 300 employee Commercial block of business; and solving for the incremental ACA fees and taxes. As we continue to execute during this challenging time for our industry, we are confident that we can achieve our 2015 projections and are well positioned to attain our 2018 goals of at least $80 billion in operating revenue and $10 in operating EPS. 
I will now turn the call back over to Tom. Tom?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sean. The Aetna management team is now ready for your questions. [Operator Instructions] Operator, the first question, please.
componenttext: Thank you, Sean. The Aetna management team is now ready for your questions. [Operator Instructions] Operator, the first question, please.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Josh Raskin from Barclays.
componenttext: Josh Raskin from Barclays.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have question for some of the comments that Mark had made around the value-based reimbursement and you seen some announcements from the Government. I guess I'm just curious from your perspective, what you think the Government is trying to accomplish? An
componenttext: I have question for some of the comments that Mark had made around the value-based reimbursement and you seen some announcements from the Government. I guess I'm just curious from your perspective, what you think the Government is trying to accomplish? And how do you think that impact Aetna's ability to serve differentiate delivery systems relative to whether it's a fee-for-service growth in the Government side or even other payers that have start sort of accelerating that change?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Josh. I think probably the most important part of what the Government is trying to do is to partner with private sector to get more value-based contracting under way. And so I actually welcome the opportunity to work with the Government because, a
componenttext: Thanks, Josh. I think probably the most important part of what the Government is trying to do is to partner with private sector to get more value-based contracting under way. And so I actually welcome the opportunity to work with the Government because, as you know, Medicare Medicaid can comprise up to 60% of hospitals revenue, and as a result, unless we have impact with the Government as a partner in this, we can't you value-based contracting along and get the kind of behavior change that we need to get as a result from the health systems themselves. So we view this as positive. We're not quite sure on details yet. We would probably like it to go faster and bigger, but I think we have a longer road there before we get to a conclusion, and we are completely comfortable with where we're headed. But so far, so good, and we welcome the opportunity.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow up on the pragmatic view on Medicare Advantage. Does this help expense effort make them a more attractive in light of the fact that providers may be looking at some of the same types of arrangements, whether it's with the Government or with
componenttext: Just a follow up on the pragmatic view on Medicare Advantage. Does this help expense effort make them a more attractive in light of the fact that providers may be looking at some of the same types of arrangements, whether it's with the Government or with your health plan?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, Josh, the genesis of our program was built off of early positive results by us partnering with health systems and Medicare Advantage by sharing with them the risk-adjusted revenue through capitation to those health systems. So I think the most i
componenttext: Actually, Josh, the genesis of our program was built off of early positive results by us partnering with health systems and Medicare Advantage by sharing with them the risk-adjusted revenue through capitation to those health systems. So I think the most important part of value-based insurance is changing the hospital, the health system model for one of revenue generation to one of margin generation the, and you can only do that by passing some of that risk and helping those health systems manage their risk. So I think for us, 6, 7 years ago, this ability to pass across risk adjuster revenue to health systems was a high moment for us in building the health generic products.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Peter Costa with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll go next to Peter Costa with Wells Fargo.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the decision to not book a receivable for the risk corridor payment relative to what you do the third quarter where I think there was an offsetting receivable relative to the adjuster?
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the decision to not book a receivable for the risk corridor payment relative to what you do the third quarter where I think there was an offsetting receivable relative to the adjuster?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Peter, that is correct. We did have that contemplated when we closed the third quarter. The decision to not do that probably strained our numbers by about $0.10 this quarter, but obviously, the performance of the core business was strong enough that
componenttext: Yes, Peter, that is correct. We did have that contemplated when we closed the third quarter. The decision to not do that probably strained our numbers by about $0.10 this quarter, but obviously, the performance of the core business was strong enough that we can overcome that. This really is a question about sort of certainty at this point. And make no mistake, we believe the law certainly says, we're of the money. We believe it's an important part of the early stages of this program. But some of the activity around the budget process and some of the guidance that came out, frankly, created a degree of uncertainty about the collectibility, and we just didn't feel like we were over the threshold to do that. In addition, I mean there is, on this whole topic, it is really important for everyone to realize what I would call the relative immaturity of the data that pertains to both the base estimates of claim experience, which is still emerging in this new program, but also the data we are using to estimate risk adjusters, is, as you know, from an outside consulting source of gathering industry data, it is certainly not the official data set upon which we will ultimately make that calculation and so there's still a lot of uncertainty. So I think when you put all those things together, it led to our decision.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just as a follow-up, do you expect to just go sometime in the first quarter or not until really the second quarter when you get the final numbers from the Government?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It will depend on what comes out on this emerging data sets, so I would say conceptually, we will directionally adjust those numbers as the data matures. But to your point, the real sort of final adjustment and the real meaningful adjustments I think will
componenttext: It will depend on what comes out on this emerging data sets, so I would say conceptually, we will directionally adjust those numbers as the data matures. But to your point, the real sort of final adjustment and the real meaningful adjustments I think will be in the middle to second half of next year when we actually get to quote the real data.

componenttext: Part of one of the reasons that we increased our overall guidance outlook for 2015 is I do think that our final negotiations on this topic are creating upside and I think sort of within the range, clearly, will be a positive or us. We've held the overall range at this point. It is still early, but directionally, it certainly is a positive factor for us, both from an earnings standpoint and a medical cost trend standpoint.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, Sean, you talked about the 49.2 on [indiscernible] it's not only 4 days higher than last year but historically high from recent perspective. Any reason to keep that high into '15 now that has implemented you have much better understanding of exc
componenttext: And then, Sean, you talked about the 49.2 on [indiscernible] it's not only 4 days higher than last year but historically high from recent perspective. Any reason to keep that high into '15 now that has implemented you have much better understanding of exchanges and so on?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of things. I would like to continue to think on exchanges that we have tried to continue to be prudent in our reserve setting. We also have a lot of really growth in our Medicaid high acuity programs with the duals where we're trying to position
componenttext: A couple of things. I would like to continue to think on exchanges that we have tried to continue to be prudent in our reserve setting. We also have a lot of really growth in our Medicaid high acuity programs with the duals where we're trying to position that appropriately. I would also say that just on directionally, the days claims payable in our Government business is a little bit longer than our Commercial business, and so some of this is just the mathematics is more of that is mixing in and more of our growth is coming from there. So I think it's really a combination of there still is some uncertainty on the new programs and we try to be prudent there, but some of it is just the the changing mix of our business.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015

componenttext: We'll go next to Andy Schenker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So maybe just to start, can you talk a little bit more of some of the moving parts in the Commercial businesses, and then you touched on it earlier but clearly there are public exchange enrollment being offset by a little bit more losses and some of the g
componenttext: So maybe just to start, can you talk a little bit more of some of the moving parts in the Commercial businesses, and then you touched on it earlier but clearly there are public exchange enrollment being offset by a little bit more losses and some of the group business, so if you could just give us a little bit more on the some of the moving parts since the analyst day.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you might -- it sounds like you're talking about volume, so let me talk about couple of things that played out. The biggest thing is around Small Group, and the most important thing there is in Small Group, 12/1, December 1, has become, because of
componenttext: I think you might -- it sounds like you're talking about volume, so let me talk about couple of things that played out. The biggest thing is around Small Group, and the most important thing there is in Small Group, 12/1, December 1, has become, because of what you have, sort of the new 1/1 in this business, so there is a good chunk of renewal activity that is now taking place in December. And at the end of today, we did better in renewing that block of business than we had initially projected. And so in many ways, if you think about business that used to be 1/1 as effectively 12/1 now, we're getting some of that growth earlier in the cycle than maybe we would've had in the past. On Individual, we continue to feel good about it. We expect, net, we'll probably throw in the first quarter from about 1 million members, both on and off exchange at the end of the year to about 1.1 million members at the end of the third quarter, with probably up to 800,000 of that being on-exchange membership.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just really quick following up on the 3Rs. So I appreciate the reversal in the risk corridor, but also the risk adjusters sounds like you're booking additional payables yourself is the interpretation here to be that your membership may have actu
componenttext: Okay. And just really quick following up on the 3Rs. So I appreciate the reversal in the risk corridor, but also the risk adjusters sounds like you're booking additional payables yourself is the interpretation here to be that your membership may have actually turned out to be a little bit more profitable than you expected, and maybe how did that influence how you ended '14 about your expectations for '15 the new population?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't know that I'd go there quite yet to say that it's going to be more profitable. And it's really not due to anything other than what I was talking about before, which is just the degree of estimation we're having to deal with all of the data so
componenttext: Yes, I don't know that I'd go there quite yet to say that it's going to be more profitable. And it's really not due to anything other than what I was talking about before, which is just the degree of estimation we're having to deal with all of the data sort of the emergent claim experience as well as the risk adjuster payable. So again, we continue to look at that data and make our best estimate off of that. We continue to feel good about this business going forward and would expect this business to be modestly profitable in 2015.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Matthew Borsch from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Matthew Borsch from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I realized it's early to talk about 2016, but what I want to ask about is your early conversations with large employers about next year, which I'm sure are already underway. And there you have 3-year-type contracts, how much is that Cadillac tax coming in
componenttext: I realized it's early to talk about 2016, but what I want to ask about is your early conversations with large employers about next year, which I'm sure are already underway. And there you have 3-year-type contracts, how much is that Cadillac tax coming into the range of discussion given your 2-year [ph] window from 2016 will bracket that? And then what changes do you see employers contemplating and where do private exchanges come into that mix?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll start with the latter part of your question first, and then I'll turn it over to Karen to talk a bit about what we're seeing on the conversations with large employers. I think we've already seen the impact of Cadillac tax on certain large accou
componenttext: Maybe I'll start with the latter part of your question first, and then I'll turn it over to Karen to talk a bit about what we're seeing on the conversations with large employers. I think we've already seen the impact of Cadillac tax on certain large accounts, particularly those that are limits of negotiating 5-year labor agreements. So I think the Cadillac tax is already playing a role. Our 3-year agreements with employers, I don't know that, that will have an impact right away unless there's a union contract as part of it, but we're already seeing it on the inside, not quite on the large employers side. So I think the real question is whether or not we have private exchange models that are stable. And I think this year, we saw less enrollment in private exchanges on part of large employers than we had anticipated and that rippled through our own private exchange membership as we participate in some of those. And maybe, Karen, you could talk a bit about what we're seeing for the large employers.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, it really is early for 2016. However, we are starting to have those conversations with our national account members. We have actually seen an increase in our pipeline even earlier this year than we did last year, it looks somewhat stronger than it did
componenttext: Hi, it really is early for 2016. However, we are starting to have those conversations with our national account members. We have actually seen an increase in our pipeline even earlier this year than we did last year, it looks somewhat stronger than it did last year as well. So we're quite pleased with the conversations that we're having and the pipeline that we see for '16. But again, it really is early.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the pipeline overall as it relates to the enrollment growth potentially for next year, what about on the private exchange side, do you see any signs building that will see an acceleration going into next year on that front?
componenttext: So the pipeline overall as it relates to the enrollment growth potentially for next year, what about on the private exchange side, do you see any signs building that will see an acceleration going into next year on that front?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We continue to have conversations around private exchanges, a lot of interest in the discussion on the private exchange, both in the National Accounts and in middle market, so we continue the dialogue and we have continued to see that interest.
componenttext: We continue to have conversations around private exchanges, a lot of interest in the discussion on the private exchange, both in the National Accounts and in middle market, so we continue the dialogue and we have continued to see that interest.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Justin Lake with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Justin Lake with JPMorgan.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question is just around the repricing of the middle-market business that you talked about in the third quarter. Can you give us an update in terms of what you're seeing on membership retention and target yields in terms of achieving that?
componenttext: First question is just around the repricing of the middle-market business that you talked about in the third quarter. Can you give us an update in terms of what you're seeing on membership retention and target yields in terms of achieving that?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd happy to, it's Karen. Relative to the 51 to 300 block, what you're referring to, as we talked about December, that block was not performing relative to our expectations so we took pricing actions. As a result, we continue to monitor those pricing
componenttext: Yes, I'd happy to, it's Karen. Relative to the 51 to 300 block, what you're referring to, as we talked about December, that block was not performing relative to our expectations so we took pricing actions. As a result, we continue to monitor those pricing actions. We're seeing what we would have expected relative to membership. And one of the things that you know we monitor is the business that stays with us versus the business that leaves us. We are pleased with what we're seeing on that we're keeping the business that we want to keep. The business that we don't want to keep, we're shedding, and it is in line with expectations. However, I would comment, again, that it continues to be early in the cycle, but so far, the performance is in line with where we would've expected it to be.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just a question on the pharmacy side. I know there were some network issues with CMS. Can you give us an update in terms of what happened there, what you're doing to fix it? And in terms of -- should we read it is there any kind of issues
componenttext: Got it. And then just a question on the pharmacy side. I know there were some network issues with CMS. Can you give us an update in terms of what happened there, what you're doing to fix it? And in terms of -- should we read it is there any kind of issues with the was a deflation of the outsourcing relationship that you have there? Or was it more internal to Aetna and adjusting view on any potential sanctions from a CMS perspective we should think about?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Justin, I would start with the sanctions we have received, the corrective action plan request, and we expect that to have marginal impact with our star ratings overall, so we believe we have this under control. We have been in constant contact with C
componenttext: Hey, Justin, I would start with the sanctions we have received, the corrective action plan request, and we expect that to have marginal impact with our star ratings overall, so we believe we have this under control. We have been in constant contact with CMS. This is a little bit the trouble with some innovation. We innovate it with our network to provide better pricing for enrollees, and we got some pushback from the pharmacy side, particularly independent pharmacies and talking to those enrollees, which created noise in the system. We have reached out. We have solved a lot of these issues so far. We are making sure that the beneficiaries are not at harm from any standpoint in getting their drugs or treatments, if necessary. We are on the phone with is everyday on this issue, we believe that we have a plan to fix this. The impact financially to us as an organization in the near term is manageable, very manageable.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just the PPM impact in terms of CVS. I mean is there any reason terms of this is part of complexity or no, you said it was just your narrow network?
componenttext: And just the PPM impact in terms of CVS. I mean is there any reason terms of this is part of complexity or no, you said it was just your narrow network?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It was just us. It was product innovation, putting different kind of product in the marketplace. We communicated it pretty thoroughly. We reviewed it with CMS before we get it. It was all approved, but you got pushback from the marketplace. And as we know
componenttext: It was just us. It was product innovation, putting different kind of product in the marketplace. We communicated it pretty thoroughly. We reviewed it with CMS before we get it. It was all approved, but you got pushback from the marketplace. And as we know and as we are very carefully to know all the time, we do not want to put the beneficiaries at risk and so we moved on very quickly. We found it, recorded it and got engaged.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Christine Arnold with Cowen.
componenttext: We'll go next to Christine Arnold with Cowen.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you speak your expectations for the duals in terms of profitability? And also, your Medicare Advantage book, how are you thinking about profitability of that in 2015?
componenttext: Could you speak your expectations for the duals in terms of profitability? And also, your Medicare Advantage book, how are you thinking about profitability of that in 2015?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll start with Medicare Advantage and toss it over to sean for the duals. On the Medicare Advantage, we saw 80% of growth so far and for this year [indiscernible] star plans, so that always bodes well from a revenue standpoint and MBR standpoint. Those a
componenttext: I'll start with Medicare Advantage and toss it over to sean for the duals. On the Medicare Advantage, we saw 80% of growth so far and for this year [indiscernible] star plans, so that always bodes well from a revenue standpoint and MBR standpoint. Those are plans that generally we have good results with, so our expectation is that we'll move margin up again for Medicare this year. That is over goal and part of our objectives. So we're happy with our Medicare performance, Medicare Advantage performance and look forward to another strong year from that organization.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And to wrap that, going back on Investor Day, we did talk about our Government MBR being essentially flat x PYD. But inside that, we are expecting to see the Medicare business improve and the Medicaid revert a little bit to more normal levels after a
componenttext: Yes. And to wrap that, going back on Investor Day, we did talk about our Government MBR being essentially flat x PYD. But inside that, we are expecting to see the Medicare business improve and the Medicaid revert a little bit to more normal levels after a very strong year. On the duals, given that it's still in the very early stages of maturity on these programs, they will certainly generate a lot more revenue in 2015, and the marginal -- the profit of these early on that will be relatively low, if any, in the early stages of these programs so it's not a big profit contributor per say. We're sickly not seeing anything now in the early stages of these contracts that would make us feel any differently than that at this stage.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Dave Windley of Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to Dave Windley of Jefferies.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Follow-up on the Medicare Advantage, you mentioned a couple of times that 80% of your growth is coming and your [indiscernible] plans. I believe that kind of an 80% mix of membership in-force our plans as your starting point also, are you surprised that y
componenttext: Follow-up on the Medicare Advantage, you mentioned a couple of times that 80% of your growth is coming and your [indiscernible] plans. I believe that kind of an 80% mix of membership in-force our plans as your starting point also, are you surprised that you're not seeing, say, disproportionate growth into your higher star plans?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not really, I think it's early. And I think it all depends on the pricing the market, relative to the marketplace. So in 0-premium markets where all price are pretty equal, I think star ratings matter. In other markets, we're all over the competitive map
componenttext: Not really, I think it's early. And I think it all depends on the pricing the market, relative to the marketplace. So in 0-premium markets where all price are pretty equal, I think star ratings matter. In other markets, we're all over the competitive map relative to our competitors, and so I wouldn't necessarily jump to that conclusion. I think we like the fact that 80% of our memberships, new memberships coming from those plans, it is the right kind of footprint for us. We're not done yet with our star ratings and moving those up. Our goal is 100%, and so I think that -- we'll continue to build on that but we're pleased. We're not at all worried.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could ask a similar question, but in the Individual market. I think you talked about bringing lots of new product to market through your ACL relationship. Could you talk about how that is influencing your membership gains in on exchange market?
componenttext: If I could ask a similar question, but in the Individual market. I think you talked about bringing lots of new product to market through your ACL relationship. Could you talk about how that is influencing your membership gains in on exchange market?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, it's Karen. relative to the on-exchange market, as you know, we extended our footprint this year to add additional market. We have put competitive products into the marketplace on the exchanges. As you might recall, our strategy was to go into market
componenttext: Hi, it's Karen. relative to the on-exchange market, as you know, we extended our footprint this year to add additional market. We have put competitive products into the marketplace on the exchanges. As you might recall, our strategy was to go into market where we had a competitive cost position where we were comfortable with over to the regulatory environment and we are we could have our return on capital. You can see from the results that we are expecting about 800,000 members at the end of the first quarter, and that is in line with our expectations and we're quite pleased with the results to date on exchange.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to AJ Rice with UBS.
componenttext: We'll go next to AJ Rice with UBS.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I might go back to asking about the days claims payable. I know you highlighted on that remarks 42.9. It's up 4 days year-to-year. Would you characterize that as a change that's related to the mix of business change? Would you say the balance sheet is mor
componenttext: I might go back to asking about the days claims payable. I know you highlighted on that remarks 42.9. It's up 4 days year-to-year. Would you characterize that as a change that's related to the mix of business change? Would you say the balance sheet is more conservative position with regards to this year to last year? And is there a target for that?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say that I wouldn't go as far as sort of forming that conclusion that we're necessarily or conservative. We had a very strong year last year on prior year development. It could certainly turn out that way, as you all know. But again, this is reall
componenttext: I would say that I wouldn't go as far as sort of forming that conclusion that we're necessarily or conservative. We had a very strong year last year on prior year development. It could certainly turn out that way, as you all know. But again, this is really driven, again, by 2 factors. Again, it's the growth in the Government business, and that's just the structural factor to the point of your question that's going to push on that number as that business grows. But as these new programs grow like exchanges, for example, like the new dual contracts, for example, we certainly are trying not to get ahead of ourselves on the reserve side. And again, I think that's one of the uncertainties. And if it turns out that we've been overly cautious, then we may get resolved more akin to what you're asking about. But at this point, I wouldn't go that far and I would say there are elements of sort of both structural change and caution regarding growth populations in that number today.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could maybe slip in on the area of co-ops has been on the news and particularly 1 co-op liquidating in Iowa and Nebraska where you guys have a presence. Can you give us a little flavor for how that changes the dynamic? Is that being a posit
componenttext: Okay. And if I could maybe slip in on the area of co-ops has been on the news and particularly 1 co-op liquidating in Iowa and Nebraska where you guys have a presence. Can you give us a little flavor for how that changes the dynamic? Is that being a positive for you? Or is there something that gives you caution? And what do you see generally around co-op activity in your exchange markets?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I will touch -- I just want to make one comment on the co-ops. We believe that the recent failure in Iowa and Nebraska is a president kind of transactions of the way we handle this is very much aimed toward it is probably is not the first or not the last
componenttext: I will touch -- I just want to make one comment on the co-ops. We believe that the recent failure in Iowa and Nebraska is a president kind of transactions of the way we handle this is very much aimed toward it is probably is not the first or not the last of these co-ops to have issues. And we want to make sure that, first and foremost, customers are not left out an alert on this, but secondly, that we obviously have the right kind of products in the marketplace. So I'll turn it over to Karen to talk a little bit about how we handle the specific situation.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've been working very closely with the state because, as Mark said, we want to ensure that access to care by those members. Essentially, the state has encouraged those members to go into the open market and that's essentially what's happening. And we ar
componenttext: We've been working very closely with the state because, as Mark said, we want to ensure that access to care by those members. Essentially, the state has encouraged those members to go into the open market and that's essentially what's happening. And we are pricing those members in accordance with the prices that we have put in the marketplace. So we're managing those individuals as we would normally manage the enrollment process, so we expect to see an increase in overall membership but priced appropriately.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ralph Jacoby from Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ralph Jacoby from Crdit Suisse.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Debt cap came up a little bit, 37%, I think from under 35%. I guess how quickly do you want to get that back down? And if a deal presented, where's your tolerance on sort of the high end where you take debt to cap?
componenttext: Debt cap came up a little bit, 37%, I think from under 35%. I guess how quickly do you want to get that back down? And if a deal presented, where's your tolerance on sort of the high end where you take debt to cap?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our commitment now is to return that debt to cap to 35% by the end of 2015, so that's what we'll be marching towards. I don't really want to speculate on sort of a hypothetical debt to cap on a hypothetical deal. Obviously, we look at every on the strateg
componenttext: Our commitment now is to return that debt to cap to 35% by the end of 2015, so that's what we'll be marching towards. I don't really want to speculate on sort of a hypothetical debt to cap on a hypothetical deal. Obviously, we look at every on the strategic merits and the financial merits of the deal, and it's all part of that equation when we make those decisions.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could squeeze other one in. You pulled forward some Coventry synergies I think last year. I guess can help us what did you capture and what sort of the incremental opportunity that we think about 2015 and maybe what they did to the assumpti
componenttext: Okay. And if I could squeeze other one in. You pulled forward some Coventry synergies I think last year. I guess can help us what did you capture and what sort of the incremental opportunity that we think about 2015 and maybe what they did to the assumptions?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the last time we updated you, I think we said something the order of $0.60 was achieved or at least that. And as Mark mentioned, we're confident that the run rate with which we're exiting the year is at least $0.90. It is, in fairness, gettin
componenttext: Yes. I think the last time we updated you, I think we said something the order of $0.60 was achieved or at least that. And as Mark mentioned, we're confident that the run rate with which we're exiting the year is at least $0.90. It is, in fairness, getting more difficult as the organization becomes more integrated to sort of keys out. That's a synergy versus that's a productivity improvement which we're working on all the time anyway. So again, we're confident that we will achieve at least the $0.90 that we committed to you when we announced the deal.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Scott Fidel with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to Scott Fidel with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question. Just if you could give us an update on how our performance has been tracking in on international and student ever since you put than corrective placing quarters ago? And then just more broadly, Mark, just interested if as you've been down
componenttext: First question. Just if you could give us an update on how our performance has been tracking in on international and student ever since you put than corrective placing quarters ago? And then just more broadly, Mark, just interested if as you've been down to Washington if you're seeing any signs at this point of any type of viable contingency strategy being developed here in terms of an adverse ruling on subsidies?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Scott, I'll handle both of those. International is performing ahead of expectations based on the changes we made in the third quarter, and student health is performing at expectations. So when you combine that with a 51 to 30, actually, the Commerci
componenttext: Sure, Scott, I'll handle both of those. International is performing ahead of expectations based on the changes we made in the third quarter, and student health is performing at expectations. So when you combine that with a 51 to 30, actually, the Commercial MBR is performing better, offset by the impact of flu in the fourth quarter and the change we made regarding risk adjusters. So I think that's how people look at the overall bridge to the MBR in the fourth quarter and for the full year. As it relates to the confiscations in Washington, I obviously been engaged we're on a number of points. And I think there is a reallocation that the revenue figure number, 10 million people into the uninsured marketplace as a result of a decision by the Supreme Court would not be a wise thing for anybody. And so I think there's a lot of conversation going on, on what kind of continuing we would need, if any, to get through the end of the year, what kind of solutions would be offered by both sides to get to a place where the program would just not abandon people. I think that conversation is ongoing. I think it is actually ongoing at this point in time, and I think there are people on both sides of the aisle who want to try and make something work should that decision come forward.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Do you think -- this is being driven sort of equally on the administration and congressional side? Or is it more biased towards one of the other at this point?
componenttext: Okay. Do you think -- this is being driven sort of equally on the administration and congressional side? Or is it more biased towards one of the other at this point?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's hard to say. I'm not involved in all the conversations, so I would say that there's probably a lot going on around this issue.
componenttext: That's hard to say. I'm not involved in all the conversations, so I would say that there's probably a lot going on around this issue.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll go next to Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the earnings release, there's a lot of talk about investment in the G&A line to fund growth initiatives, but I guess, there was a lot of commentary on the callback. Can you talk about where you were spending the money and how much we should think about
componenttext: In the earnings release, there's a lot of talk about investment in the G&A line to fund growth initiatives, but I guess, there was a lot of commentary on the callback. Can you talk about where you were spending the money and how much we should think about those investments and to get leverage on that next year or just the continued level of spending?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kevin, I think from an overall standpoint, I think our biggest investments are in health agenda continue the whole provider development and ACA process, and so that organization gets a fair amount of capital. I think on the other, though, is preparing for
componenttext: Kevin, I think from an overall standpoint, I think our biggest investments are in health agenda continue the whole provider development and ACA process, and so that organization gets a fair amount of capital. I think on the other, though, is preparing for the consumer marketplace, particularly the Swift acquisition is one. There are some things we need to do to make that platform more robust. There's also a lot of work going on in new consumer platform that is very low cost and is modular. And all of that is aimed at connecting those 2 at some point in the future, where we have this consumer platform and exchange and benefit administration platform connected to ACOs and markets that we think is disruptive and a lot of ways to the current models that we see in our marketplace. So that's where the lion's share of the investment is going. However, we continue to invest in Medicare stars and solving the funding gap; Medicaid expansion in the markets, particularly dual-eligibles. In the Commercial business, it's likely toward how do we stream operating costs and make that a better generator of capital for the kinds of investments we want to make the the future in the other items I just mentioned.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then I wanted to clarify something. On the trend line, I think you guys affirm from 6 to 7, but I thought of the Investor Day use that kind of an apples-to-apples basis, that would have been 5 to 5.5. But I think in the comments, you said
componenttext: Okay, great. And then I wanted to clarify something. On the trend line, I think you guys affirm from 6 to 7, but I thought of the Investor Day use that kind of an apples-to-apples basis, that would have been 5 to 5.5. But I think in the comments, you said it was 50 to 100 basis points increase off of where you were. I was kind of thinking 125 last time, so is there a chase there? Do 2014 base change in that delta? Or was there something else going on there?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we just -- you're right, your numbers are right, 5, 5.5. Originally, we have talked about an assumption of 50 to 100 basis points of utilization increase, but we also talked about an additional 50 basis points of unit costs, most of which was hep C. T
componenttext: No, we just -- you're right, your numbers are right, 5, 5.5. Originally, we have talked about an assumption of 50 to 100 basis points of utilization increase, but we also talked about an additional 50 basis points of unit costs, most of which was hep C. That got us into the 6 to 7 range. As I mentioned earlier, that hep C number should be better now as a result of the negotiations we've concluded. And so clearly, it's a positive factor inside that range of 6 or 7, but for the time being, we held the 6 to 7 range.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Tom Carroll with Stifel.
componenttext: We'll go next to Tom Carroll with Stifel.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sean, just a quick clarification on your 2015 quarterly comments. Are you suggesting first quarter '15 will be flat, down or slightly up from the first quarter '14 given the items you mentioned?
componenttext: Sean, just a quick clarification on your 2015 quarterly comments. Are you suggesting first quarter '15 will be flat, down or slightly up from the first quarter '14 given the items you mentioned?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, if I hold all other things being equal, it's down, right, because what I'm talking about is the absence of a better-than-typical flu season, the absence of some of the temporary benefit we got because of some of the severe weather. So I would just a
componenttext: Well, if I hold all other things being equal, it's down, right, because what I'm talking about is the absence of a better-than-typical flu season, the absence of some of the temporary benefit we got because of some of the severe weather. So I would just ask that again, when we look at the pattern that out there and we think about the pattern projecting it, that, that first quarter pattern, we should not assume at least those items recur.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think obviously how we play it will depend by segment. I think in the large employer, the national account segment, we'll need some participation from multiple carriers, which we're already engaged in conversations around. I think from a middle ma
componenttext: Well, I think obviously how we play it will depend by segment. I think in the large employer, the national account segment, we'll need some participation from multiple carriers, which we're already engaged in conversations around. I think from a middle market standpoint, it can be total replacement, and we view that as an opportunity to move people first to notional defined contribution so they can fund it in the way and create a marketplace for their employees and then to ultimately the true defined contribution, which we think is an opportunity at the high end of the middle market at the low end of the middle market obviously being insured. Now on the Individual side, obviously the public exchanges, but we see a lot of opportunity in the public exchange marketplace, particularly as we work through all the issues with the Federal Government where private exchange models that connect Medicare, Medicaid, Individual and Small Group, any marketplace and creates ubiquity or fungibility of products through 1 marketplace as an opportunity for private exchanges, including the potential for subsidy in the longer run. And so that all depends on how things work out in Washington. Where we see this private exchange model even more importantly, with the admin platform on the back-end, which most private exchange models do not have. And that ability to provide benefited administration for the employer bundles into the cost of the overall product and the private exchange experience and marketplace really creates a lot of flexibility for us to provide value to certain employer segments.
