componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Dave Windley with Jefferies.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to focus on the MBR. Could you comment on the sustainability of MBR on the Government side? Shawn, you mentioned the headwind from Kentucky rates. I'm wondering if there are other factors that we should consider? And then on the Commercial side o
componenttext: I wanted to focus on the MBR. Could you comment on the sustainability of MBR on the Government side? Shawn, you mentioned the headwind from Kentucky rates. I'm wondering if there are other factors that we should consider? And then on the Commercial side of the MBR, is the membership mix that you are seeing, that the departures of memberships, is that -- are you seeing that be favorable to your margin profile in the Commercial side of the business?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, David. Let me start with the second one because the answer is yes. As we mentioned, we are -- we push price. We're seeing a little bit of a volume pressure, but because of the way this is shaking out, we're doing fine from a margin dollars pe
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, David. Let me start with the second one because the answer is yes. As we mentioned, we are -- we push price. We're seeing a little bit of a volume pressure, but because of the way this is shaking out, we're doing fine from a margin dollars perspective, so that is -- that's going the right way. On the Government business, I think it's worth commenting on really why it's performing so well and then talk a little bit about the outlook. I would say first that both Medicare and Medicaid are performing very well. The way this is showing up has been another quarter of very strong prior-period development. Obviously, leading the pack on Medicaid is Kentucky. That continues to perform very well. And as you alluded to, we will have a rate reset in the third quarter. Medicare is really firing on all cylinders as I mentioned. The Individual M&A business, the group MA business are performing very well. And I think that's the result of investments that we made even more than a year ago but looking at making sure that we're doing as good job as we can on revenue and medical management. I also mentioned the PDP margins. The actions we took to recontact the network and do some product redesign have really taken hold, and that business is performing better. I think the thing I don't want to get lost here obviously is the fact that the Medicare business is running so much meaningfully better and very well on the second quarter. I think that's a nice thing to be taking into 2016 when you think about the bids that we submitted during the second quarter. In terms of our outlook, we are not projecting that this same very favorable level will show up in the second half of the year. Part of this is we do want to be careful not to get too far ahead of ourselves, and we're not making any assumption in terms of these ongoing very strong levels of PDP, for instance. You mentioned the Kentucky rate reset. That is certainly a meaningful items in the second half of the year, and also, there tends to be a little bit of seasonal pressure on the Medicare MBR in the second half of the year, which is related to the risk scores and the population. So I do think we still have a very good result. In fact, our forecast for these businesses certainly has been squarely in the target margin range for the full year. I do expect that the second half performance will not be as good as the first half, but again, these businesses are still performing exceptionally well.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from the line of A.J. Rice with UBS.
componenttext: The next question is coming from the line of A.J. Rice with UBS.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, just on the 3R accrual. I appreciate the commentary of how the new information has affected your 2014 assumptions and accruals. How is that reflect in your 2015 accruals? Have you made any changes to what you're doing for 2015 as a result of
componenttext: First of all, just on the 3R accrual. I appreciate the commentary of how the new information has affected your 2014 assumptions and accruals. How is that reflect in your 2015 accruals? Have you made any changes to what you're doing for 2015 as a result of the information on 2014?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. So to your point, when the data came out on June 30, we recognized that we needed to increase the risk adjustment accrual related to 2014 by about $60 million. The next logical question is what does that tell data tell you about your 2015
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. So to your point, when the data came out on June 30, we recognized that we needed to increase the risk adjustment accrual related to 2014 by about $60 million. The next logical question is what does that tell data tell you about your 2015 accrual? And we have largely assumed that the -- in our guidance and what we booked for the second quarter that the 2015 risk adjustment payables will be more or less at the same PMPM rate as the 2014 payable despite the fact that we are making substantially more investment spending to improve that result in the potential for risk pool improvement in 2015. So I think it speaks again to the strength of the underlying businesses. Not only do we have the prior period sort of catch-up adjustments we discussed, but the very fact that we're in essence sort of on plan and flat year-over-year, that's being done in essence in the face of a higher outlook for 2015, which again speaks directly to how well the underlying Commercial business is performing.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And maybe as my follow-up question, I'm going to take a shot at this. I think the 2 questions that we generally gotten since you guys have announced the Humana deal are around how can we get confident in your anticipated accretion given the v
componenttext: Okay. Great. And maybe as my follow-up question, I'm going to take a shot at this. I think the 2 questions that we generally gotten since you guys have announced the Humana deal are around how can we get confident in your anticipated accretion given the volatility in Humana's results and how we can get comfortable around the regulatory path we're going through? I guess since you announced there's been the announcement of Humana second quarter results, and there's also been obviously another deal announced so we know we've got 2 big deals before the DOJ. Any updates or any words that you would offer to try to add to comfort around either those issues?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: AJ, Mark. On the regulatory approach, we've already filed our HSR. We're starting to file in a number states. We need 20 state approvals for Form As. We will file our S-4 in the next couple of weeks. And so all of that -- so the process is underway. We've
componenttext: AJ, Mark. On the regulatory approach, we've already filed our HSR. We're starting to file in a number states. We need 20 state approvals for Form As. We will file our S-4 in the next couple of weeks. And so all of that -- so the process is underway. We've engaged in conversations with insurance commissioners. We have governors with Washington, and we are most concerned about staying on our strategy, our point of view. We're doing deep analysis even deeper than we did before the deal, the number of competitors by market plans offer, the opportunity to divest. I think if you all do your homework like you have been in all the competitors in each market and look at the markets where we may need to consider divestiture, there are plenty of competitors left in the market. And so I think our comfort is in the actual analysis at the end of the day, we will still be 8% of the overall Medicare market on a combined basis. We will not -- we will be big in the markets where we may be -- have to divest. There will be plenty of competitors in each market. And quite frankly, I think the bigger issue at the market level where this analysis will occur is the level of market share that the blues hold, which is really the dominant competitor in each market. I'll turn it over to Shawn for comments on Humana's performance today.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on the accretion, I would say there's really 3 things that certainly give me comfort that are all wrapped in the wrapper of I think we have a very reasonable and achievable financial case for them. First, we're not assuming overly rosy growth rate
componenttext: Yes. So on the accretion, I would say there's really 3 things that certainly give me comfort that are all wrapped in the wrapper of I think we have a very reasonable and achievable financial case for them. First, we're not assuming overly rosy growth rates or margin rates for their business, so we have a very reasonable I think and achievable projection for sort of the base case. I think our synergy assumption is a very achievable assumption, and we certainly have proven that we can deliver and exceed based on Coventry. But I think we have a relevant base case assumption regarding synergies. And finally, I think we've also made a reasonable provision for any disruption that might occur in a large acquisition. So I think the accretion really is premised on a case that we want to be able to have a high degree of confidence that we can deliver to you, and we would have every intention to try to not only achieve that but sort of keep that case in terms of what we end up producing.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: The next question is coming from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays Capital.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sticking with Medicare. I guess you talked about the mid-single-digit margins, so I'm just curious what you think the long-term sustainable margin is for that business? And then how does scale that play into that? Are there benefits, are there national be
componenttext: Sticking with Medicare. I guess you talked about the mid-single-digit margins, so I'm just curious what you think the long-term sustainable margin is for that business? And then how does scale that play into that? Are there benefits, are there national benefits other things you can do with PDM capabilities to capture more of that margin? Or is more MA really a business we should think about mid-single digit in each and every account that you guys did?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Josh, I believe that mid-single digit will continue to be and we view as possible for the Medicare business going forward. We believe that's an appropriate return and we can price well into that. I think the real issue is that the local market level wh
componenttext: So Josh, I believe that mid-single digit will continue to be and we view as possible for the Medicare business going forward. We believe that's an appropriate return and we can price well into that. I think the real issue is that the local market level where our presence is and our ability to partner with providers and keeping medical costs under control going forward and our ability to get the information necessary to drive star ratings and risk adjusters. If we get paid for the risk that we're assuming, then we can manage the population more effectively. And so the model really is shifting on underwriting and Medicare from one of creating balanced risk pools to one of getting paid for the risk we're assuming. And so that really depends at the local market level. I think what you're seeing in our performance this year is all the work we've done underlying those provider relationships so those collaborations we've been talking about for the number of years in addition to all the work we've been doing on the star ratings. We literally double our presence in the markets with the Humana acquisition today that works at that level of market penetration that's going to make a difference.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then, Shawn, I know there isn't an easy way to do this, but is there any way to so to figure out what is the core -- within that 7 40 guidance this year, what's the core sort of ongoing EPS growth or EPS total for the year if we
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then, Shawn, I know there isn't an easy way to do this, but is there any way to so to figure out what is the core -- within that 7 40 guidance this year, what's the core sort of ongoing EPS growth or EPS total for the year if we sort of exclude some of the out-of-period 3Rs and their way to sort of think about what the core EPS is?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, the most direct out of period is, if you look at what we did this quarter, for example, on the 3Rs, the amount that's going back to 2014 is roughly $80 million. So that's about a $0.14 bad guy that's going back to that. But I want to be real
componenttext: Well, I mean, the most direct out of period is, if you look at what we did this quarter, for example, on the 3Rs, the amount that's going back to 2014 is roughly $80 million. So that's about a $0.14 bad guy that's going back to that. But I want to be really clear that we actually -- our guidance presumes that even, including that, we can get to back to sort of in essence a flat Commercial MBR. And when you look at where we are year-to-date and you adjust for these things, you can see that that's in essence where we are. But as it pertains to do 3Rs, that's really the magnitude of the adjustment that goes back to 2014.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And there's no sort of other extraordinary favorable development or anything like that, that we should think of not really run rate for this year?
componenttext: Okay. And there's no sort of other extraordinary favorable development or anything like that, that we should think of not really run rate for this year?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we always have -- we always talk about the prior year developments, but no, there's nothing extraordinary on a year-over-year basis that I would call out.
componenttext: Well, we always have -- we always talk about the prior year developments, but no, there's nothing extraordinary on a year-over-year basis that I would call out.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Andy Schenker with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Andy Schenker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just maybe first on cost trend. You now are guiding to the low end versus maybe previously the lower half. Maybe discuss what you're seeing related to cost trend and what actually the moving parts that are driving towards that low end versus your initi
componenttext: So just maybe first on cost trend. You now are guiding to the low end versus maybe previously the lower half. Maybe discuss what you're seeing related to cost trend and what actually the moving parts that are driving towards that low end versus your initial expectations?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Andy, as you'll recall and I alluded to, we had assumed that we would have an uptick in utilization trend this year. We had included that in our forward pricing. And in the first, at least in the first half of the year, thus far, we're really not
componenttext: Yes. So Andy, as you'll recall and I alluded to, we had assumed that we would have an uptick in utilization trend this year. We had included that in our forward pricing. And in the first, at least in the first half of the year, thus far, we're really not seeing that. In our forecasting, we had assumed that we would see that more on the outpatient side. And while the outpatient trend is still positive, we're not seeing any of the acceleration that we would've put into pricing. So really what we're seeing is a stable continuation, a sort of the trend trajectory we've been on, and again, in the first half to the year, not seeing that uptick that we had put into pricing going forward.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe somewhat related to that, you did implement pricing actions with middle-market Small Group, which seems to be driving the desired outcomes for your margin expansion maybe at the expense of membership. It sounds like membership will continue to
componenttext: Okay. Maybe somewhat related to that, you did implement pricing actions with middle-market Small Group, which seems to be driving the desired outcomes for your margin expansion maybe at the expense of membership. It sounds like membership will continue to the second half of the year, but clearly you're doing quite well on margins. So how should we think about that business going forward maybe hang into next year maybe a little anniversary-ing of this year's losses. But are you at a place where you're comfortable with the margins, especially given the lower-cost trend where you think you could maybe price return to membership growth? Or is the market still competitive in those areas?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, it's Karen. Relative to your question, first, I would say that the underlying performances of the businesses performing exactly where we thought it would be. And you're right, we have had that volume pressure. We expect to see in our forecast reflects
componenttext: Hi, it's Karen. Relative to your question, first, I would say that the underlying performances of the businesses performing exactly where we thought it would be. And you're right, we have had that volume pressure. We expect to see in our forecast reflects continued pressure in the second half of the year. We are at the point, though, that we expect to -- the market, it remains competitive, and we expect to price for -- continue to price for margin over membership. But we expect to in '16 start performing better on this business and start showing better growth. There's a lot of churn in the 2 to 50 and the 51 to 100, and we have the ability to underwrite that 51 to 100 business to keep what you have activities, and we are looking to maintain that and grow that into 2016.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Andy, this is about as clear a case as there is that sort of the evidence of favoring margin over membership, and there would be no fundamental change in that philosophy going forward. These things tend to work through the rate correction cycle an
componenttext: Yes. So Andy, this is about as clear a case as there is that sort of the evidence of favoring margin over membership, and there would be no fundamental change in that philosophy going forward. These things tend to work through the rate correction cycle and how these order volume impacts but tend to stabilize more once you get through a full annual cycle of the repricing.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to understand around the 3Rs, you said you're taking actions to better understand the health of your business. Is this basically a coding initiative? What exactly are you doing to get in here -- to better understand the population? And is th
componenttext: I just wanted to understand around the 3Rs, you said you're taking actions to better understand the health of your business. Is this basically a coding initiative? What exactly are you doing to get in here -- to better understand the population? And is there any way to kind of frame or quantify what you think the benefits could be?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So in general, Kevin, you're on the right track. What we're talking about there are the kinds of things you do to ensure that you're getting fair and complete payment for the the risk profile of your membership. We're investing more energy into that in 20
componenttext: So in general, Kevin, you're on the right track. What we're talking about there are the kinds of things you do to ensure that you're getting fair and complete payment for the the risk profile of your membership. We're investing more energy into that in 2015 than we did last year. But again, the fact that this is a sort of zero-sum gain amongst participants, I want to be a little bit careful that despite the investment how much we can really back on in terms of getting that improvement. So I'd hesitate to speculate on an amount right now. And I'd go back to what we have largely assumed in our 2015 forecast is that the same level at the same rate at which we saw payables end up at a 2014, we've largely assumed a continuation of that rate in 2015 with no real improvement from any of these incremental investment and no real improvement from the potential for the risk pool that this is all settled up and to get better. Obviously, that's a bit speculative, so I would never bank on that. But we have largely assumed the run rate we just observed in 2014.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up on the investment team. You mentioned a few times G&A investments for growth. Can you just give a little color to what exactly you're spending on and what businesses that refers to?
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up on the investment team. You mentioned a few times G&A investments for growth. Can you just give a little color to what exactly you're spending on and what businesses that refers to?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Kevin, what we're investing is in our Commercial -- our consumer business, which we will launch for new products, 60 product in 4 different markets in 2016 for 11 [ph] '16 on the public exchange and public exchange for Individual market, we will also
componenttext: Yes. Kevin, what we're investing is in our Commercial -- our consumer business, which we will launch for new products, 60 product in 4 different markets in 2016 for 11 [ph] '16 on the public exchange and public exchange for Individual market, we will also be launching a private exchange version for Small Group in a number of markets throughout 2016. We continue to invest in our footprint on Medicare but we're evaluating that as we consider the integration issues around Humana and the opportunities that reside there. And we will continue to invest in our provider relationships as we build up more joint ventures and ACOs the Innovation Health Plan model.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from the line of Peter Costa with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: The next question is coming from the line of Peter Costa with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, just a clarification. On the 3R guidance and your overall earnings guidance for the year. You have not included anything for risk corridors in your guidance you paid $100 million or roughly $0.20 in earnings. That would be on top of the $7.40 earni
componenttext: First, just a clarification. On the 3R guidance and your overall earnings guidance for the year. You have not included anything for risk corridors in your guidance you paid $100 million or roughly $0.20 in earnings. That would be on top of the $7.40 earnings guidance you have?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is correct.
componenttext: That is correct.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then the second question about next year. Looking at next year, the Part D bids declined on average 7.9% or 5.7% after normalization. Can you tell us why you think those bids declined so much on average, and if you think that that's something that was
componenttext: And then the second question about next year. Looking at next year, the Part D bids declined on average 7.9% or 5.7% after normalization. Can you tell us why you think those bids declined so much on average, and if you think that that's something that was expected or should be expected based on the performance of the Part D this year?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The one thing I would tell you that there's a lot of mechanics behind that sort of national average bid process. And I think every year, we've seen people taking action around product design, network design and whatnot that have probably brought that nati
componenttext: The one thing I would tell you that there's a lot of mechanics behind that sort of national average bid process. And I think every year, we've seen people taking action around product design, network design and whatnot that have probably brought that national average bidding lower than maybe people would've thought that the beginning. That result came in largely where we had projected it was going to come in for our book of business, but it really is the ongoing actions of people to deliver a more cost-effective product to consumers.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would just add that our bids were favorably positioned to a national average bid and that we were below the low-income benchmark in 33 out of the 34 regions and right in line with our expectations.
componenttext: Yes. And I would just add that our bids were favorably positioned to a national average bid and that we were below the low-income benchmark in 33 out of the 34 regions and right in line with our expectations.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Anna Gupte with Leerink Partners.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Anna Gupte with Leerink Partners.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The question is firstly, about your Commercial MLR guidance that you updated to 80.2, and it's encouraging that it's flat year-over-year but. As you look back to when you were guiding at the beginning of this year, were you embedding or expecting any impr
componenttext: The question is firstly, about your Commercial MLR guidance that you updated to 80.2, and it's encouraging that it's flat year-over-year but. As you look back to when you were guiding at the beginning of this year, were you embedding or expecting any improvements firstly in the public exchange loss ratio from '14 to '15? I think you would expect to be breakeven? And then secondly, on the Commercial loss ratio. You had some issues on some Small Group last year. Your repriced the book, seemed very conservative. Is there any potential for MLR improvement and certainly overall that 80.2 conservative, not that it's bad result. I'm just curious if there's any upside on that.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, there's always upside to any of these estimates. I guess as well, like I said, there's all the ever-present risk of trend changing. But on the Commercial MLR, I think what I would say about that is we have pushed the repricing and what we'v
componenttext: Well, I guess, there's always upside to any of these estimates. I guess as well, like I said, there's all the ever-present risk of trend changing. But on the Commercial MLR, I think what I would say about that is we have pushed the repricing and what we've done this year in terms of trying to position ourselves appropriately for the 3Rs is a pretty significant amount of money and really the fact that we're coming in at the initial guidance again speaks to the fact that the underlying business both as a result of the pricing actions that we took last year and sort of what we're observing on trend is running at or better than expected in most instances.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then on the public exchanges, if it's breakeven last year, once you take all the 3Rs accounting and everything, what is embedded right now into your full year expectation for margin?
componenttext: And then on the public exchanges, if it's breakeven last year, once you take all the 3Rs accounting and everything, what is embedded right now into your full year expectation for margin?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you look at 2015 even without the risk corridor, this business would be slightly profitable even with the sort of higher-risk adjustment payable outlook.
componenttext: When you look at 2015 even without the risk corridor, this business would be slightly profitable even with the sort of higher-risk adjustment payable outlook.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So there's $100 million [ph] and your $277 million, which seems like very conservative on payables, there is potential flow single-digit margin?
componenttext: Okay. So there's $100 million [ph] and your $277 million, which seems like very conservative on payables, there is potential flow single-digit margin?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and again, whether -- honestly, I thought we were conservative on 2014, and so that going back to Kevin's question has sort of positioned our viewpoint and continuing to be cautious in this area and what we've accrued for 2015. And on a program that'
componenttext: Yes, and again, whether -- honestly, I thought we were conservative on 2014, and so that going back to Kevin's question has sort of positioned our viewpoint and continuing to be cautious in this area and what we've accrued for 2015. And on a program that's really still in some ways in its infancy, I don't want to get too far ahead of myself in sort of predicting that there's conservatism in that risk adjustment accrual. Clearly, the risk corridor would be meaningful upside if we were able to recognize a good part of that or all of it.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Christine Arnold from Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Christine Arnold from Cowen & Company.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: You guys I think already submitted a lot of your Individual bid for 2016. Can you go back or do you need to go back now that you have this revised outlook on the 3Rs and renegotiate kind of the phase with the Fed with respect to your public exchange prici
componenttext: You guys I think already submitted a lot of your Individual bid for 2016. Can you go back or do you need to go back now that you have this revised outlook on the 3Rs and renegotiate kind of the phase with the Fed with respect to your public exchange pricing?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Christine, we have gone back to what the states where we could, and we have repriced in a number of states reflecting risk adjusters so that has been done and we have now new prices in those states.
componenttext: Yes. Christine, we have gone back to what the states where we could, and we have repriced in a number of states reflecting risk adjusters so that has been done and we have now new prices in those states.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Christine, the thing I would add is interestingly enough, the variance that we have for 2015 is actually more in Small Group than it was Individual. So as Karen mentioned, there's always moving parts in Individual, but we're not as deep into that
componenttext: Yes. And Christine, the thing I would add is interestingly enough, the variance that we have for 2015 is actually more in Small Group than it was Individual. So as Karen mentioned, there's always moving parts in Individual, but we're not as deep into that pricing process. And in fact, it is concentrated in a few places. So I'm comfortable that we can reflect in our pricing, and this will be fine for 2016.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So those both Individual and Small Group profitability can improve next year?
componenttext: Okay. So those both Individual and Small Group profitability can improve next year?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it would be reasonable to assume that.
componenttext: Yes, it would be reasonable to assume that.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And final question for me is, how do you think about the Kentucky drag with respect to kind of margins there as you've absorbed those rate cuts?
componenttext: Okay. And final question for me is, how do you think about the Kentucky drag with respect to kind of margins there as you've absorbed those rate cuts?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: What I would say is that what we forecast sort of post this rate cut is still a profitable contract in Kentucky. I would say the margin profile going forward though looks a lot more like a typical Medicaid margin as compared to where we've been. The drag
componenttext: What I would say is that what we forecast sort of post this rate cut is still a profitable contract in Kentucky. I would say the margin profile going forward though looks a lot more like a typical Medicaid margin as compared to where we've been. The drag in this year is probably plus or minus the $0.10 that we talked about, and that's obviously for half a year. But the contract still a very good contract. It's just not going to be at the margin level that it's been at.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Sarah James with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Sarah James with Wedbush Securities.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

componenttext: Well, we've talked about that. This has been certainly both well below the mid-80s in the past. But let me be clear and I apologize that I misspoke, the $0.10 is for the second half of 2015, so it would actually represents 2 quarters.

componenttext: So we haven't gotten some direction is what I would say. One of the pieces of good news that was included in the June 30 release of the 2Rs was that in essence that the 2014 reinsurance program, there was a surplus of about $1.8 billion in that program. And they were quite explicit that any amounts that were not going to be used to make payments in 2014 would be used to make payments in the reinsurance year of 2015. And so by looking at the magnitude of that and looking at the size of what we think the pool is, to your point much akin to what we did in 2014 and looking at this issue, we concluded that this was sort of our best estimate of what would get paid out via that program.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I will -- I think as it relates to the reinsurance drivers, it is just high-cost cases. And some of them indeed is pharmacy, but they're just really people that go over that threshold. There are whole host of different cases. It's normal to the course of
componenttext: I will -- I think as it relates to the reinsurance drivers, it is just high-cost cases. And some of them indeed is pharmacy, but they're just really people that go over that threshold. There are whole host of different cases. It's normal to the course of business that we run on a day-in and day-out basis where we always have high-cost cases. We generally priced those into the premium across the total population. So what happens when the reinsurance recoveries come out of a separate category, a separate way of accruing, they have to go into pricing. And so we'll see how that plays out as we get ready for the next pricing period, but that will be the overall impact as that you'll see every -- so risk corridors and the reinsurance recoveries will have to get priced into de rates.

componenttext: And I think, Ryan, you certainly saw that one of sort of the reconciling items, if you will, in terms of rate increases from '14 to '15 was the change in the reinsurance program. That is again, to Mark's point, contemplated again in '15 to '16 pricing. And for the most part, that is what the market's doing. So I think ultimately, the answer to your question is yes based on the fact that this is largely got into sort of a sustainable pricing in the markets. I think it's reasonable to assume that the marketplace will function post-reinsurance.
